page.title: 04RIVER TAME
page.content: A small stream runs alongside Broadwell Road, Oldbury, which is part of the River Tame. Starting at Rowley Regis the river flows northwards to eventually join the sea in the Humber estuary. Before the Victorian age, the Tame was a good fishing river, but waste dumped from factories polluted it. Now in 1985 the Severn Trent Water Authority are cleaning up the river, keeping a close watch on the amounts and kinds of toxic waste dumped by local factories. The Tame in Broadwell Road is, however, often yellow because it has iron in it from the Bromford Iron Works. The ground still contains the acid which was used 50 years ago to pickle steel and this is still slowly seeping into the river.
